questions.text: The following graph explains a property of nerve fibres that is:
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

  • The graph represents a strength-duration curve, which illustrates the excitability of nerve fibres by plotting stimulus strength against duration.
  • Key parameters include:
    • Rheobase: The minimum current strength required to elicit a response when applied for a prolonged duration.
    • Utilisation Time: The time required for the rheobase current to produce a response.
    • Chronaxie: The time required for a current double the rheobase (2R) to elicit a response. Tissues with shorter chronaxie are more excitable. A decreasing chronaxie, measured from strength-duration curves over time after nerve injury, indicates nerve regeneration.

Explanation of Other Options:

All or none phenomenon (Option B): This describes action potentials occurring fully or not at all when the stimulus exceeds the threshold, as shown by the stimulus-response curve, not the strength-duration curve.

Adaptation (Option C): Also known as accommodation, this refers to the failure of nerves to fire action potentials in response to slowly rising currents, as depicted by the accommodation curve, not the strength-duration curve.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy with developmental delay has a TrkA receptor defect. Which neurotrophin is ineffective?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

TrkA specifically binds Nerve Growth Factor (NGF), so a TrkA defect makes NGF ineffective, affecting sensory and sympathetic neuron development.

questions.text: A neurologist evaluates dendritic function in a spinal motor neuron. Which statement about dendrites is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Inhibitory postsynaptic potential does not occur in dendrites is wrong statement as both excitatory and inhibitory postsynaptic potentials occur in dendrites.

  • Dendrites are the branched extensions of neurons that primarily receive synaptic input from other neurons. In anterior motor neurons, these dendrites are particularly extensive and cover a large spatial area. This wide coverage allows them to integrate thousands of excitatory and inhibitory signals simultaneously, which supports (Option A ruled out)
  • Although dendrites are critical for receiving signals, they do not effectively propagate action potentials. This is because dendrites have a relatively low density of voltage-gated sodium channels, which are essential for the regeneration and propagation of action potentials. Instead, they transmit signals in the form of graded potentials (like EPSPs and IPSPs), which travel passively toward the soma and axon hillock. (Option B ruled out)
  • Moreover, excitatory postsynaptic potentials (EPSPs) commonly occur in dendrites, especially at the postsynaptic membrane of excitatory synapses. These EPSPs are local depolarizations that occur when sodium channels open in response to neurotransmitters. These signals are crucial for determining whether the neuron will fire an action potential. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A patient with a peripheral nerve injury undergoes assessment. Which statement is true about nerve regeneration?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Regeneration is faster when the cut ends of a nerve are closely aligned (within 3 mm) and in the same line, as this facilitates proper guidance for the regenerating axons.

  • Wallerian degeneration occurs distal to the site of injury, followed by regeneration starting 3-5 days post-injury.
  • Crush injuries allow more effective regeneration than cut injuries because the Schwann cell sheath and endoneurial tubes remain intact, serving as conduits for axon sprouts.
  • In contrast, cut injuries often disrupt the alignment of nerve fibres and the guiding structures, delaying or misdirecting regeneration unless surgically corrected. (Option A ruled out.)
  • The presence of neurilemma (Schwann cells) is essential for regeneration as it produces growth factors and maintains pathways, thus enhancing, not slowing down, recovery. (Option B ruled out.)

questions.text: Given an image of a specific type of neuron, which of the following neuronal tissues do not match the type of neuron shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pyramidal cells in the motor cortex are multipolar, whereas the neuron type shown in the image (e.g., bipolar) is found in the retina, vestibular ganglion, and olfactory epithelium.

Classification of Neurons Based on Number of Poles:

  • Unipolar Neurons:
    • It has only one pole.
    • Seen during the embryonic stage in humans.
    • All developing neurons initially exhibit this morphology.
  • Pseudounipolar Neurons
    • Both axon and dendrite arise from a single pole.
    • Initially bipolar, but the two processes converge and elongate into a T-shaped process.
    • Examples: Spinal ganglia, ganglia of all cranial nerves except the 8th (vestibulocochlear) nerve, mesencephalic nucleus of the 5th (trigeminal) nerve
  • Bipolar Neurons
    • Have two poles:
      • Axon arises from one pole
      • Dendrites arise from the opposite pole
    • Examples: Retina, vestibular ganglion, olfactory epithelium, cochlea (Option A, B, & C)
  • Multipolar Neurons
    • Have multiple poles.
    • Axon arises from one pole; dendrites arise from all other poles.
    • Examples: Motor neurons in the spinal cord, pyramidal cells in the motor cortex, Purkinje cells in the cerebellum

Key Takeaway:

Pyramidal cells are multipolar neurons, unlike retinal, vestibular, and olfactory neurons, which are unipolar or bipolar.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about the axon of a neuron is most accurate?
1. Axons contain Nissl granules, allowing local synthesis of neurotransmitters.
2. Axons carry impulses away from the cell body.
3. Action potentials typically initiate near the axon hillock.
4. Axons always branch extensively near their origin to enhance synaptic integration.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Axons carry impulses away from the cell body, and action potentials typically initiate at the axon hillock. Axons lack Nissl granules, and extensive branching near their origin is not universal.

Structure and Characteristics of Axons:

  • Each neuron has only one axon:
    • Unlike dendrites, a neuron typically has a single axon.
  • Arises from the axon hillock: (Statement 3)
    • The axon originates from the cone-shaped axon hillock of the soma (cell body).
  • The initial segment is the site of action potential initiation:
    • The segment just beyond the hillock is where action potentials are first generated.
  • Conducts impulses away from the cell body: (Statement 2)
    • This is a key distinction from dendrites, which carry impulses toward the soma.
  • Lacks Nissl granules and cannot synthesise proteins: (Statement 1)
    • Axons depend on axoplasmic transport from the soma for proteins and enzymes.
  • Contains synaptic vesicles at terminals:
    • Axon terminals (especially presynaptic boutons) store and release neurotransmitters.
  • Specialised for signal conversion:
    • Converts electrical action potentials into chemical signals at synapses.
    • In contrast, dendrites handle only local (graded) potentials.
  • Axonal branching typically occurs distally (further along the axon) to reach multiple target areas, not primarily for local integration. (statement 4)

questions.text: In the graph depicting phases of a neuronal action potential, the arrow highlights a specific ionic conductance change. What does this arrow most likely represent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The arrow points to a curve representing potassium (K+) conductance, which increases during the repolarisation phase.
  • This delayed rise and fall in K+conductance reflect the slow opening and closing of voltage-gated potassium channels.
  • In contrast to sodium channels, potassium channels open later, allowing K+to exit the cell, thus restoring the membrane potential back to its resting state.
  • This K+outflow is crucial for terminating the action potential and entering the after-hyperpolarisation phase.

Explanation of other options:

Action potential in a nerve (Option A): The black wave in the background represents the actual action potential, showing phases like depolarisation, repolarisation, and hyperpolarisation. The arrow does not point to this wave, but to an ionic conductance curve; hence, this is not the correct answer.

Sodium conductance (Option B): The red curve in the graph shows a rapid rise and fall, indicating the quick opening and closing of voltage-gated sodium channels, which are responsible for the depolarisation phase. The arrow is pointing to a slower, delayed curve, not the sodium conductance.

Refractory period (Option D): This refers to the period after an action potential during which a neuron is less excitable or unresponsive to further stimulation. It is a functional phase, not a conductance curve, and cannot be represented by the arrow pointing to a specific ion conductance.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about membrane potentials?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • ↑ Extracellular K+ → ↓ K+ gradient across the membrane.
  • This leads to less K+ efflux, causing the resting membrane potential to become less negative (partial depolarisation).
  • Voltage-gated Na+ channels become inactivated at this less negative potential.
  • As a result, the threshold for action potential increases, reducing neuronal excitability.
  • K+ is the main ion responsible for establishing the resting membrane potential due to its high membrane permeability.

Explanation of other options:

Decreasing the external Na+ concentration increases the size of the action potential (Option A): Lowering external Na+ reduces the Na+ gradient, resulting in a smaller action potential amplitude, not an increase.

Change in extracellular sodium ions directly affects the resting membrane potential (Option C): The resting membrane potential is primarily determined by K+, not Na+, because the membrane is far more permeable to K+ at rest.

A decrease in extracellular calcium ions decreases the excitability of nerve (Option D): Decreased extracellular Ca²+ increases nerve excitability by lowering the threshold for Na+ channel activation (as seen in tetany)..

Key Takeaway:

An increase in extracellular potassium reduces the neuron’s ability to fire by making the resting membrane potential less negative, thus decreasing excitability.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man performs stretching exercises before a workout to prevent muscle injury. Which sensory receptor is primarily stimulated to protect the muscle from excessive tension?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Golgi tendon organ is stimulated by stretching the muscle.

Golgi Tendon Organ (GTO):

  • Located in the musculotendinous junction.
  • Responds to tension/stretch in the tendon (especially prolonged or forceful stretch).
  • Activation leads to inhibition of alpha motor neurons, causing muscle relaxation → Prevents tendon/muscle injury during overstretching

Explanation of Other Options:

Annulospiral endings (Option A): These detect sudden muscle stretch and trigger the stretch reflex, leading to muscle contraction, not relaxation, which is the opposite of what is needed during pre-exercise stretching.

Flower spray endings (Option B): These respond to sustained stretch and help maintain muscle tone, but do not play a primary role in preventing muscle damage via relaxation.

Key Takeaway:

The Golgi tendon organ is the key proprioceptor that prevents muscle injury during stretching by causing muscle relaxation in response to high tension.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male has a history of progressive muscle weakness, especially in the lower limbs, for a few weeks. He has difficulty walking. On clinical examination and with investigations, he is found to have multiple sclerosis. It is a demyelinating disorder. Which cells of the central nervous system are responsible for myelination?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Oligodendrocytes are responsible for the myelination of axons in the central nervous system (CNS).

  • Glial cells are classified into two types:
    • Microglia
    • Macroglia (includes oligodendrocytes, Schwann cells, and astrocytes)
  • Oligodendrocytes:
    • From the myelin sheath in the central nervous system (CNS)
  • Schwann cells: (Option A ruled out)
    • From the myelin sheath in the peripheral nervous system (PNS)
  • Astrocytes: (Option D ruled out)
    • Present throughout the brain
    • Two types: fibrous and protoplasmic astrocytes
    • Function: Help form the blood-brain barrier
  • Microglia: (Option C ruled out)
    • Act as immune cells in the CNS
    • Function as scavenger cells, removing debris due to injury, infection, or disease

Key Takeaway:

Oligodendrocytes are responsible for myelination of axons in the central nervous system (CNS), unlike Schwann cells, which perform this role in the peripheral nervous system (PNS).

choices.text: Inflammation and invasion by immune cells.

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient had injuries in the central and peripheral nervous systems. After a few weeks of treatment, peripheral affected nerves regained their functions by almost 50% due to the regeneration of nerve fibres. But in the CNS, it was not possible due to some factors that hamper the regeneration process. In the following list, which factor/s is/are the reason/s?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Regeneration is poor in the CNS due to inhibitory factors like CNS myelin (from oligodendrocytes), activated microglia, and inflammation with immune cell invasion.

Peripheral Nervous System (PNS) Regeneration:

  • Peripheral nerve damage can be reversed with proper therapy.
  • Schwann cells guide axons to the distal stump for regeneration.
  • Adhesion molecules (from the immunoglobulin superfamily) promote axon growth.
  • Neurotrophins support neuronal survival and axonal regrowth.
  • Inhibitory perineural molecules help direct axons along the correct trajectory.

Central Nervous System (CNS) Regeneration:

  • Regeneration in the CNS is rare and limited.
  • The proximal stump may form short sprouts, but reconnection to the distal stump and new synapse formation are unlikely.
  • Inhibitory factors in the CNS include:
    • Myelin sheath components (from oligodendrocytes) (Option A)
    • Astrocytes
    • Activated microglia (Option B)
    • Glial scar formation
    • Chronic inflammation
    • Immune cell invasion (Option C)

Key Takeaway:

Unlike the peripheral nervous system, the central nervous system has limited regenerative capacity due to inhibitory factors such as CNS myelin, microglial activation, and inflammation.
